title: Color Vision Screening (Ishihara Test)
description: Screens for red-green color blindness using an abbreviated 14-plate Ishihara test. Assesses the most common types of color vision deficiency in clinical practice.

parameters.name: correct_plates_right_eye
parameters.description: Number of plates correctly identified by the right eye (out of 14 plates tested)

parameters.name: correct_plates_left_eye
parameters.description: Number of plates correctly identified by the left eye (out of 14 plates tested)

parameters.name: visual_acuity_adequate
parameters.description: Is visual acuity 20/100 or better? Test is less accurate below this threshold

parameters.name: patient_age
parameters.description: Patient age in years. Test is less reliable for children under 5 years old

result.name: color_vision_assessment
result.description: Color vision screening results with recommendations for both eyes

ranges.interpretation: 12-14 correct plates indicates normal color vision. No further testing needed unless clinical suspicion remains high.
8-11 correct plates suggests possible color vision deficiency. Consider repeat testing or ophthalmology referral.
0-7 correct plates indicates likely color vision deficiency. Ophthalmology referral recommended for formal evaluation.

references: Ishihara S. Tests for Colour-Blindness. Tokyo: Kanehara Trading Inc; 1917.
Birch J. Worldwide prevalence of red-green color deficiency. J Opt Soc Am A Opt Image Sci Vis. 2012;29(3):313-20. doi: 10.1364/JOSAA.29.000313.
Dain SJ. Clinical colour vision tests. Clin Exp Optom. 2004;87(4-5):276-93. doi: 10.1111/j.1444-0938.2004.tb05062.x.

Perera C, Chakrabarti R, Islam FM, Crowston J. The Eye Phone Study: reliability and accuracy of assessing Neitz color vision with smartphone technology. Am J Ophthalmol. 2015;160(5):944-50.e1. doi: 10.1016/j.ajo.2015.08.014.
formula: Scoring: >2 incorrect plates out of 14 total plates indicates color vision deficiency. Each eye is tested independently.
notes: The Ishihara test is the most widely used screening tool for red-green color blindness
Abbreviated 14-plate version provides efficient screening while maintaining accuracy
Test sensitivity approximately 92%, specificity approximately 100% for red-green deficiencies
Less accurate for patients with visual acuity below 20/100
Less reliable for children under 5 years old due to attention and comprehension limitations
Primarily detects protanomaly (red-weak) and deuteranomaly (green-weak) color vision defects
Does not reliably detect tritanomaly (blue-yellow) color vision defects
Smartphone/tablet applications can show comparable accuracy to physical plates when properly calibrated
Patients with suspected color vision deficiency should be referred to ophthalmology for comprehensive evaluation
Consider occupational counseling for individuals with confirmed color vision deficiency
Not a definitive diagnostic test - formal color vision assessment may be needed
Can be used to screen for acute optic neuropathy (such as optic neuritis) in clinical settings
